questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with  palpitations, vomiting, diarrhea and marked agitation following an abrupt discontinuation of her antithyroid medication following a UTI. On examination, she is diaphoretic with proptosis and diffuse neck swelling with prominent jugular pulsations . Vitals are pulse: 120/min, BP 160/100 mm Hg, RR 24/min Temp: 39 C. Which of the following is best drug for managment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B)  Propylthiouracil

Explanation:

  • Hyperadrenergic symptoms like palptiatons, tremors, sweeating with hyperthermia in a grave's disease patient (diffusely enlarged thyroid with proptosis ) and abrupt discontinuation of medication and Infection points to Thyroid storm. 
  • The drug of choice for thyroid storm and initial treatment to be given is Propylthiouracil, which reduces peripheral T4 to T3 conversion. Propranolol in this patient should be given with extreme caution as finding of heart failure ( prominent neck veins is mentioned) . Option C, Liothyronine will worsen the patient. 

Standard Drug Sequence for Thyroid Storm 

  1. Block peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 – PTU  ( harrison mentions it as drug of choice) 

  2. Block production of T4   – Iodine (Lugol’s or SSKI) given after PTU

  3. Steroids (hydrocortisone)

  4. Propranolol (also blocks concersion of T4 to T3). Use with caution if heart failure occurs

  5. Sequester thyroid hormone – Cholestyramine 

  6. Ice packs , oxygen and IV fluids judiciously 

Thyroid Storm

Clinical Features
  • Fever with diaphoresis.
  • Cardiovascular Involvement: Tachycardia (>140 bpm), heart failure, arrhythmias, hypotension, and risk of cardiac arrest.
  • CNS Manifestations: Agitation, delirium, anxiety, psychosis, or coma.
  • Gastrointestinal Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, abdominal pain, intestinal obstruction, and acute hepatic failure.

Management
  • Initial Supportive Measures: IV fluids, oxygen, cooling blankets, and acetaminophen.
  • Beta-blocker Therapy: Start with propranolol immediately (40-80 mg every 4-6 hours) to control adrenergic tone. 
  • DOC: Administer propylthiouracil (500-1000 mg loading, then 250 mg every 4 hours) or methimazole (20 mg every 4-6 hours). 
  • Iodine Solution: Give SSKI (5 drops every 6 hours) after thionamide to reduce the release of thyroid hormone 
  • Glucocorticoids: Hydrocortisone (100 mg IV every 8 hours) or dexamethasone (2 mg every 6 hours).
  • Cholestyramine (Bile acid sequestrant): 4 grams orally 4 times daily for severe cases to reduce enterohepatic recycling of thyroid hormone.
  • Surgery: Thyroidectomy for patients with contraindications to thionamides after pre-treatment.
  • Definitive Treatment: Recommend radioiodine therapy or surgery for hyperthyroidism once stabilised.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate preoperative management to prevent thyroid storm in a pateint of grave's disease who is scheduled for total thyroidectomy?

choices.text: Start propranolol 7 days before and perform surgery once heart rate normalizes
Start methimazole and wait till acheiving euthyroid status
Start methimazole, potassium iodide, propranolol and wait till achieving euthyroid status
Take consent for high risk emergency surgery with careful intraoperative monitoing

questions.solution:
Answer is C: Start methimazole, potassium iodide, and propranolol and wait till achieving euthyroid status

To prevent thyroid storm during thyroidectomy in a patient with severe hyperthyroidism due to Graves disease, it is essential to render the patient euthyroid preoperatively.

  • Methimazole is started to inhibit thyroid hormone synthesis, and once hormone levels begin to fall (typically after a few days), potassium iodide is added 7–10 days before surgery to inhibit hormone release (the Wolff-Chaikoff effect) and reduce gland vascularity.
  • Propranolol is used to control adrenergic symptoms and also slightly inhibits peripheral T4 to T3 conversion. 

 

The Burch-Wartofsky scoring system is used to help diagnose thyroid storm:

Interpretation of Burch-Wartofsky score:

  • ≥45 points: Highly suggestive of thyroid storm
  • 25-44 points: Impending thyroid storm
  • <25 points: Unlikely to represent thyroid storm

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of multinodular goitre undergoes a CT angiogram with iodinated contrast for suspected pulmonary embolism. Two weeks later, she presents with palpitations, heat intolerance, and weight loss. Her thyroid function tests show suppressed TSH and elevated T3 and T4. Which of the following best explains this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Jod-Basedow effect

Explanation:

 

The patient shows features of hyperthyroidism, which occurred after receiving iodinated contrast during a CT angiogram. This Iodine-induced hyperthyroidism is called the Jod-Basedow effect, which occurs due to increased iodine trapping leading to Increased T4, T3 production.

 

Wolff Chaikoff effect & Jod Basedow effect

Feature

Wolff-Chaikoff Effect

Jod-Basedow Effect

Definition

Temporary inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis in response to high iodine exposure

Iodine-induced hyperthyroidism

Mechanism

High iodine levels inhibit thyroid peroxidase, reducing T3 and T4 production

Excess iodine stimulates autonomous thyroid hormone production in susceptible individuals

Duration

Temporary (usually resolves in 1-2 weeks)

Can persist until treated

Thyroid Function Tests

Initially decreased T3 and T4, increased TSH

Increased T3 and T4, decreased TSH

At-risk Population

Normal thyroid glands

Pre-existing thyroid disease (e.g., multinodular goiter, Graves' disease)

Clinical Presentation

Usually asymptomatic or mild hypothyroid symptoms

Symptoms of hyperthyroidism (e.g., palpitations, heat intolerance, weight loss)

 

Hashitoxicosis (Option D): This refers to transient hyperthyroidism caused by the release of preformed thyroid hormones during the early inflammatory phase of Hashimoto thyroiditis. It’s not related to iodine exposure or multinodular goitre.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a 2-week history of palpitations, anxiety, and weight loss. On examination, her heart rate is 110 bpm and regular, and she has a painful goitre. Thyroid function tests show decreased TSH level and elevated free T3 & T4 levels.  A thyroid scan shows very low uptake. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Subacute thyroiditis

Here, thyroid scan / RAIU scan shows very low uptake, indicating thyroid gland is not active, but free T4 and T3 are elevated due to inflammation of the thyroid gland indicating thyroiditis as a cause of this patient's condition.

  • Subacute thyroiditis (de Quervain thyroiditis) is an immune reaction of thyroid gland (tender thyroid gland) that follows an upper respiratory tract infection (viral infections).
  • From the given options, Subacute thyroiditis is one of the causes for thyrotoxicosis without hyperthyroidism. During the thyrotoxic phase of Subacute thyroiditis, there is a transient release of stored thyroid hormones (T3 and T4) into the bloodstream due to the inflammation of thyroid tissue.
  • The thyrotoxic phase usually lasts for several weeks, followed by a hypothyroid phase and eventual recovery.

Causes of thyrotoxicosis without hyperthyroidism include:

  • Subacute thyroiditis
  • Silent thyroiditis
  • Factitious thyrotoxicosis
  • Radiation/Amiodarone/Infarction of a large tumour

The other options (Options A, B, D) cause thyrotoxicosis due to hyperthyroidism, meaning the thyroid gland is actively overproducing thyroid hormones (high uptake on RAIU scan).

questions.text:
35-year-old woman presents with a history of weight loss, palpitations  and heat intolerance. On examination, she has a diffuse goitre, ophthalmopathy and fine tremors in her outstretched hands. Her thyroid function tests show:

TSH: < 0.01 mIU/L (normal range: 0.4-4.0 mIU/L)

Free T4: 35 pmol/L (normal range: 10-20 pmol/L)

Free T3: 12 pmol/L (normal range: 3.5-6.5 pmol/L)

Which of the following is the most likely cause of her hyperthyroidism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Graves' disease

This patient's presentation is most consistent with Graves' disease, which is the most common cause of primary hyperthyroidism. The diagnosis is supported by:

  1. Young age (typically affects women between 20-50 years)
  2. Symptoms of hyperthyroidism (weight loss, palpitations, heat intolerance)
  3. Diffuse goitre on examination
  4. Presence of ophthalmopathy
  5. Suppressed TSH with elevated free T4 and free T3

Option A will have same blood work but will have asymetrically enlarged thyroid gland. Option B will have elevated TSH while our patient has low TSH. Option D is seen with toxic multinodular goiter

questions.text: 50 year old patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation. Diagnostic work up showed high T4, high T3 and high TSH. Which of the following is next best investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer is A: MRI head 

The lab report indicates secondary hyperthyroidism. The usual cause is thyrotroph pituitary adenoma for which MRI head needs to be done. Other options are for finding cause of priamry hyperthyroidism like grave's disease or toxic multinodular goiter.

questions.text: On the Thyroid function test, TSH is suppressed, Free T4 level is normal, and Free T3 is increased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) T3 thyrotoxicosis

  • The patient's clinical presentation suggests T3 thyrotoxicosis, which is supported by the suppressed TSH, normal Free T4 and increased Free T3 level.
  • T3 thyrotoxicosis occurs due to increased peripheral Deiodinase enzyme activity, which converts free T4 to free T3.

Additional Tests for Aetiology:

  • Anti-TPO (thyroid peroxidase) antibodies: Positive in Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
  • TRAb (TSH receptor antibody) or TSI (Thyroid Stimulating Immunoglobulin) (Option C)
    • For Graves' disease diagnosis
    • Used to predict remission after antithyroid drug treatment
    • Important in pregnancy to assess risk of fetal/neonatal thyrotoxicosis
  • Thyroglobulin (Tg)
    • Elevated in all types of thyrotoxicosis except factitia
    • Main use: follow-up of thyroid cancer patients post-treatment

Imaging Studies:

  • Thyroid Ultrasound 
  • Radioactive iodine uptake scan: While useful in differentiating causes of hyperthyroidism (e.g., Graves' disease vs. thyroiditis), it is not the immediate next best step. It is the next step after TFT shows a hyperthyroid picture.

questions.text: RAIU scan was performed for a 35 year old lady with hypertension and palpitations. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Graves' disease 

In Graves' disease, there is diffusely increased uptake of radioactive iodine throughout an enlarged gland, often described as a "hot" appearance.

 

Thyroid scan:

  • Thyroid scans use radioactive iodine (I-123) or technetium-99m to assess thyroid function and structure on RAIU scans.
  • Increased uptake indicates hyperfunction, while decreased uptake suggests hypofunction or thyroiditis.
  • The pattern of uptake helps differentiate between diffuse (Graves') and nodular (toxic adenoma, multinodular) causes of hyperthyroidism.
  • Thyroid scans are useful when TSH is suppressed to determine the cause of hyperthyroidism.

 

Interpretation:

  • Normal Thyroid: Uniform uptake throughout the gland.
  • Graves' Disease: Diffusely increased uptake throughout an enlarged gland.
  • Toxic Multinodular Goiter: Multiple areas of increased and decreased uptake. (Option A)
  • Toxic Adenoma: Single area of increased uptake with suppression of surrounding tissue. (Option D)
  • Thyroiditis: Very low or no uptake due to inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue. (Option C)
  • Thyroid Cancer: Usually appears as "cold" nodules (areas of decreased uptake).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with palpitations, weight loss, and heat intolerance for the past 3 months. On examination, she has a diffuse goitre and mild proptosis. Thyroid function tests show suppressed TSH and elevated free T4 and T3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- C) Start propranolol and carbimazole

  • The clinical presentation and thyroid function tests are consistent with Graves' disease. The most appropriate initial management is to start antithyroid medication (carbimazole) along with a beta-blocker (propranolol) to control symptoms.

 

Management:

  1. Antithyroid drugs (ATDs): First-line treatment, especially in younger patients. Carbimazole or methimazole is preferred over propylthiouracil due to the lower risk of hepatotoxicity.
  2. Radioactive iodine (RAI) ablation: It is used in older patients, those with recurrent disease after antithyroid drugs, or those with contraindications to antithyroid medications. It's contraindicated in pregnancy and can worsen ophthalmopathy, especially in smokers. (Option A)
  3. Surgery (total thyroidectomy): Surgery is reserved for patients with large goitres, those who have failed medical therapy, or when there's a need for rapid control of hyperthyroidism. It's not the first-line treatment due to potential surgical complications and the need for lifelong thyroid hormone replacement. (Option B)
  4. Beta-blockers: Beta-blockers like propranolol are used to control adrenergic symptoms until the patient becomes euthyroid with ATDs.

 

MRI brain (Option D): MRI of the brain is done when the TSH levels are elevated along with the Free T3 & T4 levels. It helps diagnose Pituitary adenoma which can lead to secondary hyperthyroidism.

 

Secondary Hyperthyroidism:

Secondary hyperthyroidism refers to excessive thyroid hormone production due to extrathyroidal causes.

Causes with Treatment:

  1. TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma:
    • First-line: Transsphenoidal surgery to remove the adenoma
    • If surgery is contraindicated or unsuccessful:
      • Somatostatin analogs (e.g., octreotide, lanreotide) to suppress TSH secretion
      • Dopamine agonists (e.g., cabergoline) may be effective in some cases
      • Radiation therapy for residual tumor
  2. Pituitary resistance to thyroid hormone:
    • Beta-blockers to manage symptoms
    • Treatment to manage any associated pituitary abnormalities
  3. hCG-secreting tumors:
    • Treatment of the underlying tumor (e.g., choriocarcinoma, hydatidiform mole)

 

In all cases, beta-blockers may be used to manage symptoms of thyrotoxicosis until definitive treatment takes effect. Antithyroid drugs are generally not effective in secondary hyperthyroidism as they do not address the underlying cause of excessive TSH production.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Answer is D: Diarrhea

Diarrhea is seen in hyperthyroidism while constipation is seen in hypothyroidism. 

Serous cavity effussions are seen in hypothyroidism due to myxedema. Myxedema reduces lymphatic outflow / drainage of Lymph that explains the development of both pericardial and pleural effusion in these patients . 

Deposition of mucinous material of  GAG in the transverse carpal ligament and surrounding soft tissues  causes median nerve compression  and numbness, tingling, weakness in the hand.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct description of myxedema seen in patients with hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Answer is Option B: Accumulation of dermal glycosaminoglycans

The patient's symptoms, including fatigue, weight gain, dry skin, and non-pitting edema (myxedema), points to hypothyroidism. In hypothyroidism, there is an accumulation of glycosaminoglycans  in the dermis that binds to water, leading to non-pitting edema of skin. 

The yellowish tinge to the skin in the case is due to carotenemia, common in hypothyroidism due to reduced conversion of carotene to vitamin A.

The dry skin is a hallmark of decreased thyroid function, which reduces sebaceous and sweat gland activity

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes with complaints of extensive hair loss, menorrhagia and weight gain. Work up shows elevated TSH , low T3, low T4 levels and anti TPO antibody present status. She has no known cardiovascular disease. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step regarding this patient?

choices.text: Start liothyronine (T3) 5 μg three times daily
Observe and repeat thyroid function tests in 3 months

questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Start levothyroxine 100 μg daily

Start levothyroxine 100 μg daily is approximately the full replacement dose ( 1.6ug/kg) for a healthy adult without cardiovascular disease. Levothyroxine increases oxygen consumption of heart and giving full dose in patients with coexistent heart disease can trigger angina. 

Other options

A: Levothyroxine 25 μg daily  is too low and is used for elderly or patients with heart disease to avoid precipitating arrhythmias or angina.

C: Liothyronine (T3) 5 μg TID is used in myxedema coma 

D: Observe and repeat in 3 months: We have to be proactive in this case

questions.text: A known case of autoimmune thyroiditis presents with confusion and seizures. EEG shows generalized slowing without epileptiform discharges. Vitals are pulse 60/min. BP 120/100 mm Hg and temp 37.2 C. Work up shows High TSH, low T4, low T3,  blood counts and CRP is normal. Which of the following is correct about diagnosis and management?

choices.text: Thyroid storm and NG tube Propylthiouracil

questions.solution:
Answer is A: Hashiomoto encephalopathy and hydrocortisone 

Patient is having Hashimoto thyroitidis with confusion and seizures due to hashimoto encephalopathy. EEG in hashimoto encephalopathy shows diffuse slowing with low voltage or even electrocerebral inactivity in severe cases and reflects global cerebral depression due to profound hypothyroidism. 

 

Myxedema coma is seen with intercurrent infection in hypothyoridism patients and presents with hypothermia. In our case body temperature is normal and acute phase reactants are also normal ruling out possible infection. EEG in myxedema coma shows severe cerebral suppression like a metabolic encephalopathy.

Thyroid storm occurs in patients with hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: Most common cardiovascular finding in case of young female with Grave's disease is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a: Sinus Tachycardia 

The increased sympathomimetic drive caused by exccess of thyroid hormones causes sinus tachycardia as commonest features. Atrial fibrillation is also seen but in age group > 50 years and resolves when anti thyroid medication is started in more than 50% of cases. 

High cardiac output produces bounding pulses and wideneded pulse pressure beside aortic systolic murmur due to hyperdynamic circulation. This can cause worsening of angina or heart failure in elderly patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about Grave's associated opthalmopathy?

choices.text: Occurs in the absence of hyperthyroidism in 10% of patients
Earliest manifestation is proptosis and diplopia
Can cause loss of vision and papilledema
Lid lag can occur in causes other than grave' disease

questions.solution:
Correct answer is B)  Earliest manifestation is proptosis and diplopia

The earliest manifestations of Grave's ophthalmopathy are a sensation of grittiness, eye discomfort, and excess tearing . Proptosis > 22m and EOM involvement causing dipolopia  will take time to occur. 

Option A is favourite of your examiner body and is a fact. Remember it verbatim: Occurs in the absence of hyperthyroidism in 10% of patients implying that initially only features will develop. 

Option C: Extensive proptosis due to limited space in orbit will put pressure on optic nerve causing blindness.

Option D: Lid lag sign is due to sympathetic stimulation and will occur in all causes of thyrotoxicosis apart from Grave's

questions.text: In a patient with suspected hyperthyrodism, what is the initial screening test to be consindered?
questions.solution:
Answer is A: TSH and unbound T4 

Hyperthyroidism implies increase function of thyroid gland causing over production of T4. Majority of hormone is bound to TBG and thyroxine binding pre-albumin. The free /unbound T4 levels are hence to be tested with TSH. First we demonstrate a disease and then we find the etiology. So remaining options like USG or RAIU are to find the likely etiology of this presentation.
